title-group.article-title: Accurate residual wireless channel simulation using a two-tier Markov model

contrib-group.aff: School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (SEECS), National University of Science and Technology (NUST), Islamabad, Pakistan

abstract.p: Accurate models of wireless channels are a necessary pre-requisite for correct simulation and analysis of wireless protocols, applications and systems. However, commonly used wireless channel models do not correctly capture the characteristics of a real channel mainly because these models ignore either the frame-loss process or the bit-error process. In this paper, we propose a novel two-tier Markov model in which a frame-level model is executed first and the bit-level model is excited only when the frame-level model produces an error. We compare the accuracy of the proposed model with several existing models using four independently collected sets of wireless (802.11 and 802.15.4) residual bit-error traces. We validate the accuracy of the proposed model using the bit-error rate, frame-error rate, cumulative distributions of error and error-free bursts, and information divergence measures. We show that the proposed two-tier Markov model generally provides better accuracy than other models.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Adnan Iqbal received his BSc (Hons) and MSc in Computer Science degrees from International Islamic University (IIU), Islamabad in 2001 and 2004, respectively. He has recently completed a PhD in Information Technology from the National University of Science and Technology (NUST), Islamabad. His research interests include wireless channel modeling, reliable data delivery in wireless channels and energy management in cyber physical systems.

Syed Ali Khayam received his BE degree in Computer Systems Engineering from the National University of Science and Technology (NUST), Pakistan, in 1999 and his MSs and PhD degrees in Electrical Engineering from Michigan State University in 2003 and 2006, respectively. Since February 2006, he has been an assistant professor at the School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (SEECS), NUST. He has more than 70 publications in reputed journals and conferences. His research interests include analysis and modeling of statistical phenomena in computer networks, network security, cross-layer design for wireless networks, real-time multimedia communications, modeling of social networks and software defined networking.
